item.title: Link vs XRP — 50 replies — 200.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
Link vs XRP

Open thread • Replies: 50 • Updated: 2026-02-24 19:37 UTC

OP

When will the gap close? Link came within a hair of flipping xrp in January ‘21. We all know that Link is everything Xrp fraudulently claims to be so it makes sense that this chart should flip soon enough. Will it be gradual or violent? Will it flip because xrp crashes or because Link moons?

Most importantly where are some places you can use Link as collateral to borrow Xrp to take full advantage of the trade of the century?

Early replies (first 3)

61889606
I'm so tired.

61889622
>>61889600
>>61889606
>>61889620
Link is scam

Buy XRP

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61891035
>>61889600
Thanks spammy.

>>61889620
/thread

61891717
>>61891011
I'm not. It is literally the products they are building and the material they are releasing detailing it to shareholders. Link sell directly to retail every time there is a minor pump. You are literally saying nothing but standing in a way where you think if you come across as affirmative in a direct way it will seem like you are. Lol You are just doing what you accuse me of (which I am not) saying we can't trust it to be true because it is relying on the words of someone. It literally isn't. They are structuring XRPL core amendment pushes and having their staff code them based on the product suite fit detailed in the article. They made multiple multibillion dollar acquisitions, including a fucking prime broker to actuate it all. And most importantly, the majority of their treasury is in XRP and their products are ALL made more efficient and cost efficient using it and they are incentivized to increase the price of XRP they have in escrow and cannot sell, unlike CLL who dump what was supposed to be operator rewards on retail always and are LITERALLY a fraud designed to milk your savings (exactly what you project Ripple to be, which it isn't because the XRPL actually solves efficiencies instead of sticking a tollbooth in the middle of process for literally no reason like a jewish parasite). The entire XRPL is designed to automatically use XRP for auto-bridging between assets etc. Your argument sucks and it is hilarious that it actually applies to link, which you are capable of seeing but literally don't care because you are in a literal cult pretending to object but just obsessively committed to a project that is the least morally redeemable or utility having one in all of crypto for literally no reason than ego and entrenched specific coin cultism. Really odd and gay.

61891755
>>61890083
Extreme cope. SWIFT said it would take 15 years MINIMUM to even get a product active. I am not sorry to let you know that by that time SWIFT will have 100% missed the boat and payments will have been completely revolutionized, not needing them. You hitched your dingy to a big ship, but it turned out it was the Titanic, which we all always said. Way too little way too late presuming the ethgate lawfare would win but it didn't.
>>61890250
>MPT/permissioned dex is the standard
No it hasn't. You literally don't know what either of those things are. No other ledger at scale has a built in dex and amm and protocol layer compliance like permissioned dex nor the broadness of the MPT standard. It definitely has been The Standard, but not in the way you think. MPT is not "wrapped assets." Here is an AI slop video that is actually informative which possibly someone at your level of research will be able to be spoonfed by:
https://youtu.be/3kYXW_o-N4Y

61891914
>>61890307

61892108
>>61891887

Also may I just congratulate you on your point that ripple is incentivised to increase the price of Xrp since that is most of their treasury, unlike CLL who also has most of their treasury in Link but is not incentivised to increase the price. I thought that was most salient.

>>61889600
Dunno man, but the best times with link have been when I forgot about it during the bear and came back to big gains

61892185
>>61891717

61892337
>>61892108

And they never will.

61892414

61892515

when the token will be needed for functioning of the network

61892592

61892659
>>61892185
I already mentioned it you fucking retard. You can see the ledger amendment history that they have spent their own dev money and time developing, their acquisitions of Hidden Road, etc. their getting binance listing RLUSD on the XRPL, the fact the early team specifically coded the ledger to explicitly default to its use and to save several percentage points over Ripplenet alone by doing so, the fact that they locked the vast bulk of their corporate treasury up in timed release in it, the fact they fund and partner with multiple large banks to drive and encourage its use and adoption, and the fact the services they are building out literally optimize using it and offer counterparty-less feature that no other asset onchain can, and the fact that they already use it in their business. They literally legally can't use it in most contexts yet but with clarity their business can become much more efficient and as a result their core holding increases in value. There is LITERALLY no reason to argue they are not building for its use other than being butthurt that it is true and trying to repress reality like a faggot. They literally have Fednow service providers running XRPL nodes and big banks who are their largest outside investors issuing bonds that reward in XRP (who were celebrated recently in their specific crypto efforts by the financial regulator of Japan) and are partnering with DBS (biggest bank in Singapore (Switzerland of Asia) and Franklin Templeton (trillion plus dollars AUM) building out a repo market on the XRPL. They got ONDO issuing on the XRPL, one of the largest asset managers in Europe/England doing same while basically no one is getting headway in England, Societe General (one of biggest banks in Europe) expanding to include XRP for their euro stablecoin which can bridge to RLUSD using XRP, etc. Literally everything they do builds around corporately driving XRP's adoption, literally just fleshing out a business sweet around it.

61892679
>>61892659
>>61892185
This isn't even 10% of what could be said partnership etc. wise. XRP and link are different in that XRP actually improves business performance and has a reason to exist and incentivizes use in products. Link is literally just a toll booth jew token to insert costs where they would not technologically exist.

61892688

61893028

Which is hilarious. Anyway buy silver crypto fags.

Kek
SACRIFICE SPAMMY 2026

61893980

hate 'em

61895158
>>61892659
just look up xrpl code documentation and you will see what a grifter project it is. The hard fact is that no one (relatively speaking) compared to EVM based chains is using it. anything tokenization wise or project wise absolutely PALES against ethereum, thats a hard fact

>nuh uh, its used by dubai!!!!! and usage will increase 10000000x in the next few months because of institutions!!!
yea, sure what if it doesn't?
Transaction count has been going down overall, just check xrp stats

61895471
>>61895158
>and usage will increase 10000000x in the next few months because of institutions!!!
Ironic, link has the same problem. At least cripple requires you own some exerpies to do transactions on their network, unlike cucklink.

61897045
>>61895158
Eth activity pales in comparison to Canton or Base for RWA. XRP literally just overtook solana in RWA and is increasing faster than any other in the top 10, which again, it is rising through, literally just entering the RWA space like a few months ago. You faggots were saying "no one is using RLUSD/they are using it on ETH" not even realizing how retarded it sounded saying no one was using a token that launched 1 year ago at the time (which has meteorically risen since) or having understood the obvious play of liquidity vacuuming from eth by establishing presence there and tapering into XRPL use which is exactly what they are doing. To you it not immediately having the marketcap of tether and deliberately sacrificing openness the existing liquidity base in a strategically retarded play is evidence of your own rightness. XRP began seeing tokenization basically immediately after the SEC appeal was dropped after it endured 5 fucking years of lawfare through Ethgate, during which eth was retardedly given the regulatory free pass by Clayton/Gensler and co. across this entire time being used to mint assets and establish itself with an artificial legal advantage baked in by the Epstein crowd literally because it could not compete technologically and is expensive and slow and fragmented with none of the same capacity for a universal protocol level compliance features or the broadness of MPT or escrow capability etc., having to cobble together standards across issuers and bake VERY centralized trust into the model and force us into L2 end service Hell. The CCP and JPM bought 95% of ETH in the ICO and tried to subvert actual defi and crypto and trojan horse us into digital slavery hell rather than allowing better technologies to win that can scale at L1 with built in compliance capabilities. Same reason they deliberately subverted bitcoin's build to be unusable as cash without scaling into shitty turbo-centralized L2s that are still too slow and expensive.

61897098
>>61895158
>>61897045
XRP is certainly having to play catch up for the literal sole reason that it was targeted for lawfare despite ETH very obviously being much closer to a traditional security than it with XRP not even having had an ICO, but claiming victory now is pretty fucking retarded and acting like people will just continue to use worse tech for no reason other than that they did before. This is like saying low cost highspeed rail transport or refrigerated semis would be rejected because horse and buggies and old school carrier automobiles exist and we can strap big engine onto them if we wanted and industry corporatists alligned to fight them early on. At one point the same argument would have been equally valid (completely retarded). Or saying banks will use bitcoin for high frequency payments. This is obviously retarded. We are in the late 90s in the internet technology analogy. We literally don't even have regulatory clarity for market structure yet. But it is all coming together now, many will be wiped out, the level regulatory playing field will change a LOT and it would have been fucking retarded to say Netscape won internet with unassailable moat because it was so dominant early (where is it now?). XRPL is being built out as the liquidity base of core institutional services, repo market between trillions AUM Franklin Templeton and DBS (largest bank in Singapore (Switzerland of Asia)), used by ONDO with the creator of ONDO launching a video detailing how RLUSD offramps and XRPL can be used to link Black Rock's BUIDL to other member participants' in ONDO (Wisdom Tree, Franklin Templeton etc.) other products etc. You are claiming to have won because you were allowed to tie your biggest challenger's arms who only needs a few innings to crush you, in the first two innings, and you STILL didn't even win vs. others in pic related. Lol XRPL payment volume has been going UP while ALL markedly of crypto has been going DOWN.

61897113
>>61895158
>>61897045
>>61897098
Further, XRP has proportionately outperformed any other asset over the last several years of launch in ETFs, and crushes every other crypto based one that launched alongside it, ESPECIALLY link, despite literally launching the day after the big downturn started months ago on MUCH smaller early issuers than other products.

item.title: European funds for an american — 42 replies — 168.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
European funds for an american

Open thread • Replies: 42 • Updated: 2026-02-24 19:38 UTC

OP

I want to put 20% of my account in foreign, but not all foreign is created equal.

I predicted the rise in the polish economy. It's very simple, a homogenous white country free from communism is always going to become rich. A diverse country full of communists like Canada and South Africa is going to get worse and worse.

I also predicted that the real-estate market in Croatia would sky rocket due to whites fleeing countries like the UK. I was right.

So.... are there any good mutual/index funds that target the white regions of Europe, that an American can invest in? Is there a Balkans fund? A Baltic fund? Norway/Finland fund (not Sweden or Denmark)? I do not want to invest in the UK, France, Germany, or Spain.

Early replies (first 3)

61890485
>finland
>white

61890499
>please buy my bag
nein. Death to every communist, that includes every single member of a political party, everyone over 50, every bureaucrat and every single subsidized "private" which in europe is every company.

61890518
No fucking way those numbers on finland are right. I live in Helsinki and it’s like 25% brown.

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61891164
>>61890868
This is in fact, old data.

>>61891134
Yes. That's why I said funds that invest in Norway and Finland, but not Denmark and Sweden. I know Finland isn't really Nordic but they're next door.

61891236
>>61891154
That's fine but from the average person's perspective you can't understand the bigger economic picture and appreciate the vast differences in market size and capital flows.
Life for average people may be more or less similar in Croatia and England but the English stock exchange is in another universe compared to these small economies.
As I said, I'm an American living in Latvia. My life is better in Latvia. I'm just a normal guy. The top 1% and .01% would see things quite differently. Where does one park $100,000,000 in the Baltics?
Answer: you don't. And downstream from that is YOU don't get to invest $50,000 in an Estonia market ETF either. These are frontier markets not even as developed as Brazil or India.

61891243
>>61891003
Euskadi

61891374
>>61891236
I think real-estate, and downstream from that medical services, are pretty simple by and large because they're mostly just a matter of predicting the migration patterns of middle class white people, while avoiding the political behavior of lumpenprole voters. At a bare minimum investing in medical services and realestate are a safe bet in any communist free white flight destination.

Question then becomes, what financial products are available to me that resemble that in any way.

There's a fund called NHCBHFFT that invests in real estate in estonia, for example.

61891396
>>61890472
>I do not want to invest in the UK
FTSE100 has been outperforming the S&P500 for a while now but okay

61891622
>>61891396
I want a stock that will perform well long term, the UK, like Canada and South Africa, has not future unless it claws it's way back from Weimar conditions. The massive white flight that has already taken place and has been accelerating, looks exactly how things looked for Detroit, Chicago, Oakland, Baltimore, etc...

Ghettofication is an economy killer. Because people ignore it and it makes people irrational, that is the area an investor can exploit.

61892062
>>61890472
Brown migration is stagnating across Europe and so is the birthrate of migrants of the 2nd/3rd generation. The number of migrants are not big enough to not be outbred in the long run.

61892245
>>61890472
This is probably based on early 90s data when Bulgaria was full of gypsies, France was full of North Africans, but the rest of the countries were fine.
Now Bulgarian gypsies are also abroad and the roles are reversed, lol (except for France, that's only getting worse).

61892365
>>61892062
sounds like copium

61892695
>>61892062
White flight is the real economy killer. Again, look at all the places already mentioned. Niggers in america don't have exceptional birthrates but once they're 20% of a city everyone else runs away. Same as true for states and countries. Most nigger cities in America have half the population they had the in 60s. Akron and Cleveland have lost about half of their population due to white flight.

61892982
>>61890855
This.
I’m polish and I can explain a bit just to give a gist.
Poland’s “capitalist” period started in ‘89 so to this day the biggest companies included in WIG20 are completely controlled by National Treasury. So 8 of them constitute about 55% of the index.
So mind you by loading up on indexes you’re not really buying innovation rather iron clad businesses that aren’t really growth oriented.
Let’ take an example of searching for growth sectors like everyone talks about polish developers so it would be safe to assume that IT stuff has growth potential.
And here the biggest IT company is CD project which makes fucking games a dying industry that will be killed by small teams with ai making indie games.
Rest of well known IT firms are privately owned or controlled by ventures.
It’s hard to really find good stuff I personally think you should search for companies making tangible products or services example solar panels, beauty sector, pharma.
We’ve got a lot of ecomerce, construction, pharma/cosmetics, news outlets. Not really innovative stuff.

I mean I wish it was different but really if someone made something meaningful here he would be molested to death by venture capital like CVC Capital Partners and eventually cave in take cash run and live a beautiful trad life in Bielsko Biała.

61893067
>>61892982
Cont.
So to comparing to the US, Poland is a polar opposite.
In the US Capital lobbies politics. In Poland the only people who can lobby are foreign players and people with political power. And this political power has more influence on the stock market while in the US stock market and capital makes politics.
The end communist era ripples through Poland up to this day. The people responsible for the transition made themselves very powerful and control the capital to this day. The good news it that their descendants are retarded beyond comprehension and will be unable to maintain power.

61895024
>>61892695
They will just flee from one city to another, Germans aren't moving from Germany to go to fucking Poopland lol

61895226
>>61890472
>Balkans
ha haha hahahahahahaha

61895249
>>61893067
That doesn't sound like good news

61895250
>>61890472
South Korea, Japan and Brazil.
Lmao if you want to put it into Europe.

61895308
>>61890472
Check how cucked European stocks are with regards to taxes.
The only European stocks i would invest in are stocks listed in London Stock Exchange for this reason.

61895312
>>61895226
The Balkans are probably majority white now, because all of the gyppos are here in Finland and other Nordic countries.

61895890
>>61890472
Look into EU military companies. Saab, Rheinmetall etc. have had huge growth and are still on the rise.
Also whatever alternative renewables there are. (Things like synthetic fuels and deep geothermal)
Also companies that are processing rare earths and minerals. It is expected that the Europeans will start to extract those resources soon. The usual structure is that companies from outside the EU can mine, but are contractually obligated to sell most of the resources to companies inside of the Union for processing.

Also tech is fine. Plenty of EU countries are turning their backs towards US tech. Many government offices are currently swapping to different software, mostly open source. Expect EU companies to code scaleable European solutions soon.

61895901
>>61890472
>Pole pretending to be amerifat in order to brag about his all white country that for some reason has the biggest diaspora of europoors.

61895911
Now that the Netherlands introduces a retarded tax on unrealized gains (after letting in milliions of low IQ migrants) Switzerland stands alone as an investable country in Europe. Barring a few microstates.

61895912
Don't invest in Norway even though this is a fake thread made by a pole to brag about his shithole. Anyone wealthy in Norway is looking for an exit.

61895983
>>61895901
I'm from Ohio.
Like 90% of white people in Ohio, I'm Irish and German.

>>61895912
Norway will continue to be a place for whites to move to so long as it remains whiter than sweden. White flight is the biggest predictor that kikes and faggots ignore. You can only beat the market when there is something that makes the professionals behave irrationally. Race and Politics make people behave irrationally. Thus racist investing is the ultimate way to beat the market.

61895991
>>61895911
Countries that are developing after finally being free from communism, are going to be the countries with the most growth potential.

Kind of retarded if you can't understand how a country that has only been free for a couple decades has more development opportunity than a mature country where everything has already been built and now there's this massive parasitic government that has grown fat off the riches.

61896194
>>61895983
You think there will be substantial white flight to Thailand?

61896239
>>61896194
Asia is a different topic.
But the high IQ Asian countries that are becoming capitalist later than their neighbors, have the most growth opportunity. So I think Vietnam is the next south Korea.

61896307
>>61895312
wrong just like in india there's gorilion more to go

61896368
>>61890518
That's probably an old map also browns are settled at the main city

61897083
>>61895983
>Thus racist investing is the ultimate way to beat the market.
I thought that when I bought a Russian ETF and that money is now frozen and probably gone forever.

61897116
>>61893067
>The good news it that their descendants are retarded beyond comprehension and will be unable to maintain power.
They just have to be ruthless and savvy, not necessarily smart. It's hard to lose when you start the game at the finish line resting on a pile of gold while everyone else scrambles to work their whole life to buy a house.

item.title: Mac minis are the new ASIC miners — 46 replies — 147.1/hr
item.content:encoded:
Mac minis are the new ASIC miners

Open thread • Replies: 46 • Updated: 2026-02-24 19:19 UTC

OP

Mac minis are like the ASIC miners except they do actual work instead of mining bitcoin for no reason.

Early replies (first 3)

61893585
>>61893434
What are people even doing with their 50 mac mini AI agents?

61893611
>>61893585
Its like a team of 50 indians

61893612
>>61893611
Just imagine the sound of 50 echoing good morning sirs

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61895152
they are not actually hosting models on those minis lmao, its set up solely so that openclaw doesn't disintegrate the OS of your main daily driver computer which often happens

61895163
>>61894122
>The latest apple minis are 5x faster than equivalent costing PCs at running AI
Pure bullshit and you don't know shit about technology.

The unified memory bandwith is nice but you only get real benefits with something like M3 Ultra and even then, a properly set up PC inference workstation with real GPU's will beat the macs token times by a fair margin

The problem is with current RAM prices and how scarce GPU's with decent VRAM are the Mac is actually a viable alternative to putting a rig together, even if it gets a bit less tokens per second.

61895191
What does AI actually do?

61895196
>>61895191
Create asset bubbles.

61895198
>>61895191

61895251
>>61895191
What do You actually do?

This message was written by:
50 macs

61895338
>>61893611
imagine the smell

61895344
>>61895338
jej is make me laugh

61895377
>>61893611
minus the shitting?

61895732
>>61895163
>even then, a properly set up PC inference workstation with real GPU's will beat the macs token times by a fair margin
Not at the same price

61895740
>>61895377
Plus they can work 24 hours a day

>>61895338
Apple shouldn't actually produce smells because it's considered a premium product

61895757
>>61895191
Glorified googling program.

I’ve tried to use AI to diagnose some tricky health issues I’ve had and while it did help at first, I’m pretty sure it eventually tried to kill me.

61895762
>>61895732
If it was 'the same price' people would choose the faster option, aka notMac. The problem with the cheap option here being - again - you can cool GPUs and they are somewhat designed to be ran at high temps for extended periods. Mac Minis weren't and aren't. And these retards are going to fry their Mactrash, abusing them 24/7 as retarded AI agents.

61895788
you really don't need a mac mini, old Lenovo Thinkcenters work perfectly fine and you get get a used one with 32GB of ram and 2 TB of disk space for like $200-300

I have been using a few with Unbuntu installed to run a bunch of agents on an isolated Vlan at home. (These things are honestly security risks, don't give them access to your home network or personal info)

61895820
>>61895757
chatgpt is useless now, its a glorified yes man. You can actually trick it into giving horrific advice. Which puts it at the level of a 32 year old life coach, nothing more. Gemini is a good tool if you can get a local unit to run, great for helping map and document trades. But nothing more than that, if you really needed something to bounce ideas off of it isn't that. But that is all you can expect out of it, a really good calculator. It's when people expect it to be a thinking breathing human is when problems arise

61895868
>>61895788
And what model can you on 32gb ram? Thinkcentres dont have dedicated gpu do they?

61895888
>>61895868
no one is running the actual model locally, this is for running the agent and all its tools, most people are running API calls off Openrouter

61895922
>>61895888
These ARE running local models, that's the entire point of using MacMinis and unified RAM. Whether the Minis will survive the experience, is another issue entirely.

61896004
>>61895757
Interesting.
Mine kept saying im trans. Kek!
> sadface.jpg

61896011
>>61894156
>>give the mac mini all of my personal info, financial data, passwords, internet browsing history etc.
It's a personal computer. It already has all of those things.

61896031
>>61895820
Yes that’s pretty much it. Although it did help me diagnose leaky gut issues and initially helped with some supplements, but then it started telling me to basically OD on magnesium and electrolytes.

61896090
>>61894238
Rent it to people that are scared of running it locally or too stupid to figure it out.
Stuff like this https://seafloor.bot/

61896126
Basically in the future everyone will have their own personal agentic AI, and these people are hosting them while its still hard to get it set up.
This isnt a sustainable business model tho, because its only a matter of time before soke big company like google starts doing it with infinitely more success because they actually have all the data from everyone, so the AI assistant will come out of factory already knowing you better than you know yourself.
But it will be profitable probably for a 1 or 2. I dont see this stuff getting released by a big company before its tested enough to ensure most of the nightmarish stories being reported about openclaw have a close to 0% chance of happening.

61896174
>>61893434
>they do actual work
how much money has your agent made?

61896193
>>61895922
No they aren't. They're just a bunch of iToddlers who can't into Raspberry Pi or Linux.

61896922
>>61896126
>knowing you better than you know yourself
it's actually pretty hard to personalize large language models, so dont expect the same behaviour as you have from your tiktok or youtube algorithm

61896954
this is pure retardium. the minis are not running shit. they can't run any models, and anyways open models are not worth running, they're dumb as rocks
openclaw uses api to run, claude because it's the only one that can do shit. the fattest claude (the only able one) can burn hundreds of $$$ per day. and you don't need a mac mini for it. you can just run it on the cloud or in a virtual machine. it's really lean on resources - you just need to pay a lot of money for the api
dumb. all of it is just dumb

61896995
>>61895757
Must be a canadian llm, MAID GPT.

61897015
>>61896193
It's the same software. If you can't into linux then you definitely can't into macos. Both start up into a first class GUI and both require you to drop to the command line to install LLM shit because that's how the software works. Ollama front ends not withstanding.
Hell, raspi clusters are easy mode because it far easier to find a prebaked recipe you can copy/paste to get it all running whereas mac users have to deal with retards hardcoding paths and cuda bullshit into their workflows.
That said there is some retardation going on with the mac buying. Macs are the sane choice because they are the absolute cheapest way to get more than 64GB with GPU access to that pool. Your 128GB of DDR5 and a xeon doesn't compare. Buying a joblot of 16GB mac minis is defeating the purpose though.

item.title: /smg/ - BUT WHOSE SIDE IS HE ON??? edition — 32 replies — 128.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
/smg/ - BUT WHOSE SIDE IS HE ON??? edition

Open thread • Replies: 32 • Updated: 2026-02-24 19:36 UTC

OP

First mistake.

>spent 20 dollars on gas just to get to the only dealer that accepts bullion in my area
Have you tried not living in Alaska?
>pawn broker says they only pay 90% of spot price, including a 12% processing fee
So they pay 2% over spot...Nice
>IRS also collects 28% in taxes
Common misconception that precious metals are taxed at 28%. The reality is that you owe tax according to your income bracket which means that if you make around $60k per year you only owe 12% on precious metals capital gains. If you make $600k+ per year then yes you will owe 28%.
>halfway there, spending another 20 bucks on gas, my back left tire blew out.
What does this have to do with silver?
>didnt have a spare
You make $600k per year and you can't afford a spare tire???

ALGO - tranny dump already happened, was leading DiFi platform and was pretty decent for dApps. Dead now that all of that is dead.

ICP - muh Caffeine app builder and distributed compute. Only "real" token to do a 1/1000x (2k -> $2)

LINK - honestly, I am not sure what LINK does, something about oracles and sending JSON objects

GOLD - more gooder if Iran bombed?

XRP - I don't know what XRP does, is it like a replacement for USDC for replacing FedWire? Banks aren't ready to adopt it yet and still use USDC. Also not sure what it does.

???

Serious question though, which of these or similar can pump?

Also, if you want to tell me what they do, I would genuinely appreciate it. I only really understand ALGO and ICP.

Imo buying across any mix of the following will be solid longterm:
XRP, QNT, CC, XDC, ALGO (possibly dead, but in quantum age may shine for sake of superior tech), DAG, HBAR, XLM, SUI, SEI, APT, FLR, ONDO, NOM, ADA, HYPE, SOL, POL, ATOM, DAG, AAVE, DOT, VET, ZRO, RED, HYPE.

Here is a pretty good rundown of the XRP use cases at present from specifically Ripple's operation perspective:
https://ripple.com/insights/institutional-defi-on-xrpl-scaling-real-world-finance-with-xrp-at-the-core/

61891947
>>61891060
Ripple's whole strategy is (just like RLUSD launching on Eth and moving to XRPL) to meet the liquidity where it is and move it to the XRPL. Multiple banks already use XRP but many cannot until Clarity passes. XRPL optimizes using XRP and minted assets autobridge using it between different stable coin or minted asset issuances etc.

>>61890886
Most of those chains are kinda dead now that DeFi and Dapps are old news, but there are--supposedly--a dozen or so council member use cases being worked on by Hedera council members, some of which are transferable, so could be adopted by other enterprises. That seems interesting. Repsol and Fed Ex are recent members and all new members are required to have a use case they are working on, and supply chains and energy tracking seem good fits for DLTs. Will take a looooong time, though, of course.
I really don't know if crypto has another pump-n-dump fad like NFTs, DeFi, Dapps etc left in it. It really might just be the long wait for mainstream institutional adoption (another reason why I rate Hedera over most others).

61895078
not a single coin does anything

you know how when you go to a convenience store and all the different scratch-offs have different names but they're all exactly the same thing? fancy packaging for what appears to be different themes but all designed to trick you out of your money

thats what altcoins are, there are no exceptions, and everyone in the market understands this by now

61895159
>>61890886
honestly, its way more bearish that prediction market coins aren't up bigly

61895162
>>61891947
why would banks use rlusd or xrpl as a bridge currency when they can just atomically swap stablecoins? Theres no nostro-vostro in crypto, underlying assets can be sold anywhere instantly at any time, even automatically via smartcontracts or even put into liquidity pools for any overhead

61896947
>>61895162
XRP is natively used on the XRP in cross minted asset swaps at a fraction of the cost and speed of off or cross ledger settlement with basically bottomless on demand liquidity so that low volume corridors don't get blown out and weird continuous markets don't need to be developed for an efficient universal system. XRP also has none of the risk inherent in smart contracts, is completely counterparty-less and using ILP the whole thing can scale to literally trillions of tps with fees paid in any currency, capable of micropayment batching. XRP is less risky, has no counterparty or contract risk and scales liquidity regardless of the currency pair instantly with no need to establish liquidity between the currency pairs let alone specific issuer walled garden tokens (USDC vs. USDT vs. RLUSD vs. every other national etc. stablecoin) and costs less and finalizes faster. Literally every single reason they would be considering is better done this way, with a few frictions as technically possible with current DLT and zero middlemen unless they choose to have them, completely decentralized, being able to atomic swap on ILP through their own chosen structure.

61897000
>>61895078
>jeet can't read solidity

item.title: The War with Iran — 7 replies — 21.8/hr
item.content:encoded:
The War with Iran

Open thread • Replies: 7 • Updated: 2026-02-24 19:19 UTC

OP

A geopolitical risk premium is priced-in to all parts of this market right now.

We see a 3 different potential scenarios:

1. US makes deal with Iran: Stocks rise, commodities fall

2. US does "one-time" strike with Iran: Brief volatility which ends with stocks rising, commodities falling

3. US enters prolonged war with Iran: Stocks fall, commodities rise

Our positions win in 2 of the 3 scenarios outlined above, which we believe are more likely than #3.

If the US truly is setting up for a long war with Iran, then this would be highly bearish for equities, bullish for crude and gold.

Why don't we think this is the case?

President Trump wants $2/gallon gas and wants to be the "Peace President." None of these objectives are obtained in a prolonged war with Iran, particularly with mid-term elections on the horizon.

That is our current mindset on how we are approaching this market.

Reminder that we already have AGI

Open thread • Replies: 15 • Updated: 2026-02-24 18:56 UTC

Early replies (first 3)

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61892250
>>61889694
he meant anal gay intercourse, and it's the only true statement he ever made in his entire life

61893402
>>61889731
It isn't coming. LLMs are useful for some things but the notion that they are going to anything other than a glorified search engine needs to die. Yeah they are good a being a search engine, search engines are useful, but they suffer from the same problems as search engines, namely that a internet search can never actually tell you if the information it find is accurate.

Research needs to look an entirely different direction if they want true intelligence. We've been working on text generators for decades so it shouldn't be surprising that we've managed to perfect them, but the next breakthrough is going to come from something else we've been working on for decades, not from incremental improvements to LLMs.

Who knows, maybe LLMs can aid in the research of this alternative field which will bring the next advancement? Using better technology to do research can cut down the years required so the accelerated nature of technology remains, but it is still going to come from somewhere people aren't expecting.

LLMs can still be useful, but the costs associated with it are going to become prohibitive. Eventually they are going to just be like railways or telecoms which serve as an expensive base over which the next thing can emerge.

61893571
AGI is here as of two months ago, it's openclaw when using anything smarter than Opus 4.5. Companies are beginning to hire mac minis instead of people. If you still want to meme about r's in strawberry and pretend this isn't happening, that's at your own risk. You'll be out of a job sooner rather than later. My "glorified search engine" just built a whole tradingview clone for me and i cancelled my subscription.

61893608
ps, you should download a copy of the tradingview free charting library now. Because once they notice the potential damage it'll cause to their subscription profits they'll move it behind a B2B paywall

61893618
>>61889716
Lololol

61893632
>>61893571
>job
Sir this is a business and finance board

61893850
>>61893571
Producing a charting library for you is indeed a "glorified search engine". Impressive no doubt, but all it really is doing is copying something that already exists. Like you said it wouldn't work without the library. So it is just searching and displaying things in a proper way. This seems very "Star Trek" where you can command a computer to display stuff for you, but it is still an unthinking computer doing this. It is not AGI, it is going to do a particular sets of tasks extraordinarily well, but it can't do everything.

Incidentally in terms of the economics of computing, having everyone needing to use an LLM to produce their own software clone is enormously inefficient. It makes sense right now only for two reasons:

1. Using AI is basically "free" for the end user. They aren't paying any associated costs yet.

2. Software is currently held back behind paywalls creating artificial scarcity.

AI in practice is unlocking tons of value that is blocked by intellectual property laws, but getting around intellectual property laws is coming at the expense of mounting physical costs. We could have Free Software that is made efficiently and given away for cheap and that would be far less resource intensive that using LLMs to make personalized versions of everything for everyone.

It is a bit like the phenomena of computers constantly bloating in memory requirements because they have greater capacities. Old software was incredibly efficient, using only kilobytes, but now it uses gigabytes. AI produced software is using terrabytes. This trend will continue until our software demands become impossible to fufill in the real world.

In Computer Science there is a concept of complexity, which is how quickly something grows when its unit demands increase, and in some cases it might be linear, quadratic, or exponential. Other cases it is logarithmic and it is proportionally less intensive the more it is used. While now we are "hyperscaling", that can't last forever.

61894075
>>61893850
> all it really is doing is copying something that already exists
that's not how ai works. It learns the probability of existing text patterns from training data, and then uses those probabilities to output original text. Which isn't the same as copypasting existing github repos

and that chart library is only like half my codebase. It got the app up and running quickly but if I wanted to I could have the ai replace that file in a day or two

61894111
Whether it's the US or China who reaches AGI first, they will not be making it public nor implement it into public LLMs for a very long time. The military and intel community will get first dibs for national security reasons
